G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19-21.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19-21, as the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Worcester County.

G.L. c. 84, \u00a7 13.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of care under G.L. c. 84, § 13 to maintain the sidewalk abutting her property in a reasonably safe condition and to remove snow and ice reasonably.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..raw_text: Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 933 N.E.2d 50 (2010)
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a duty on property owners to ensure that sidewalks abutting their property are reasonably safe for public use.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: Papadopoulos concerns a slip-and-fall in a private parking lot of a shopping mall, not on a public sidewalk abutting the defendant’s property. The opinion explicitly distinguishes that third track of law dealing with public ways and recites that abutting owners had no duty to keep public sidewalks free of natural snow and ice; it does not hold that Massachusetts law imposes a general duty on property owners to ensure abutting public sidewalks are reasonably safe for public use. The case’s holding is about abolishing the natural/unnatural distinction for hazards on the owner’s own premises, not about duties as to public sidewalks.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “There was a third legal track, not relevant here, for injuries suffered by a plaintiff on a public way, including a sidewalk and roadway, that abutted a defendant’s property. ‘The owner or occupant of premises abutting on a public way is under no obligation to keep the sidewalk free of snow or ice which came there from natural causes.’ Bamberg v. Bryan’s Wet Wash Laundry, Inc., 301 Mass. 122, 123-124 (1938).”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 296 N..proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, landowners have a duty to protect invitees against unreasonable risks of harm.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 296 N..support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and adopting a general negligence standard. The court held that landowners/occupiers owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to protect them against unreasonable risks of harm, which subsumes the traditional invitee-protection rule. Although the excerpt is a concurrence focused on trespassers, the majority opinion clearly establishes the duty described in the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 296 N..relevant_excerpt: (From the majority opinion) "We hold that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors… The proper test of a landowner's liability is whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others… The plaintiff was entitled to the protection of the defendant’s duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent injury from unreasonable risks of harm."

Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc..raw_text: Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 638 N.E.2d 17 (1994)
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc..proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has held that landowners are responsible for addressing unsafe snow and ice conditions on their property or abutting sidewalks.
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns premises liability for a slip-and-fall on ice, but it emphasizes that a landowner is not liable absent actual or constructive notice of the hazardous condition and notes the traditional rule that failure to remove a natural accumulation of snow or ice does not violate the duty of care. It does not announce a broad rule that landowners are responsible for addressing unsafe snow and ice conditions on their property or abutting sidewalks; instead, it affirms judgment for the defendant because there was insufficient evidence of notice. Thus, it does not support the claimed proposition and in context cuts against it.
Barry v. Beverly Enterprises-Mass., Inc..relevant_excerpt: “In sum, the jury could not reasonably have inferred that the defendant violated its duty of reasonable care by failing to remove the ice or to warn the plaintiff of a potential hazard. … This conclusion is consistent with our cases indicating that a landowner’s duty of reasonable care ‘is not violated by a failure to remove a natural accumulation of snow or ice,’ Sullivan v. Brookline, supra at 827, since one of the reasons for that rule is that ‘in this climate … [ice may form] without fault of the owner and without reasonable opportunity on his part to remove it or warn against it or even to ascertain its presence.’”} 출장쇄기 연동마지막.}

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.raw_text: Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 652 N.E.2d 567 (1995)
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: The doctrine of foreseeability applies here, as the hazardous condition created by the Defendant's failure to salt or sand the icy sidewalk was plainly foreseeable.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss icy conditions, salting, sanding, or a landowner’s duty regarding snow and ice; it concerns a claimed duty to install a pedestrian bridge or traffic signal and control of a state highway. While the case mentions general premises-liability duties and proximate cause, it is focused on duty and control over public highways, not on foreseeability of an icy sidewalk condition. Using this case to support a proposition about foreseeability of hazards from failure to salt or sand an icy sidewalk would be inaccurate and out of context.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “Before liability for negligence can be imposed, there must first be a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, and a breach of that duty proximately resulting in the injury. … It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

Mastrangelo v. West End Realty Corp., 27.raw_text: Mastrangelo v. West End Realty Corp., 274 Mass. 451 (1931)
Mastrangelo v. West End Realty Corp., 27.proposition: The Defendant’s failure to remedy the icy condition caused Plaintiff to slip and fall, a foreseeable harm under the circumstances.
Mastrangelo v. West End Realty Corp., 27.support_reasoning: The case concerns a landlord’s failure to provide adequate heat leading to a constructive eviction and the tenant’s right to vacate and stop paying rent. It does not involve ice, slipping, falling, or personal injury, nor does it analyze foreseeability of such harms. The opinion is about contract/landlord-tenant remedies, not premises liability for icy conditions, so it does not support the proposition claimed.
Mastrangelo v. West End Realty Corp., 27.relevant_excerpt: “There was ample evidence to warrant the jury in finding that there was a constructive eviction of the defendant under the first lease for failure of the plaintiff properly to heat the premises therein described… The evidence warranted a finding that during the winter months the plaintiff failed properly to heat the premises occupied by the defendant under both leases; that the defendant and his employees suffered from the extreme cold by reason of the failure of the plaintiff to carry out his agreement to furnish heat …”

Kulda v. Parker, 371 Mass. 582 (1976).proposition: The Defendant’s failure to remedy the icy condition caused Plaintiff to slip and fall, a foreseeable harm under the circumstances.
Kulda v. Parker, 371 Mass. 582 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the validity of ‘John Doe’ tax assessments and tax takings on Nantucket property and does not involve any slip-and-fall, icy conditions, premises liability, or foreseeability of physical injury. It addresses tax law and land title issues only. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a defendant’s failure to remedy an icy condition foreseeably caused a plaintiff’s slip and fall.
Kulda v. Parker, 371 Mass. 582 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “The basic question to be decided by the Court is whether an assessment of property to John Doe, a fictitious person, and a taking after nonpayment of the taxes so assessed is a valid tax taking pursuant to which the owner’s right of redemption may now be foreclosed.”
